cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the institutions, issues and legislation affecting the employment relationship in the public and private sectors in Canada, with emphasis on collective bargaining. The economic and political environment, history of the labour movement, union organization, certification, contract negotiation, strikes, dispute resolution, contract administration and grievances.
cmCourseInfo.title: Labour Relations
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment in the Employment Relations program (ASSPE1535/ASMAJ1535) or 4.0 or more FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3.

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Timetable Instructions
ACORN does not check for prerequisites/exclusions in real time. These will be checked by the Program Office staff throughout the summer session. Students enrolled in courses for which they do not have the published requirements may have their registration in IRE courses cancelled at any time. For course details click on the course code in the timetable below and review the course description, prerequisites etc. before enrolling in a IRE course. The registration date for WW CHRM students is March 1, 2019. Contact the Program office (IRHR@utoronto.ca) if you have any questions about IRE courses.

cmCourseInfo.description: Introduction to the nature of organizations and the behaviour of individuals and groups within organizations, including topics such as culture and diversity, reward systems, motivation, leadership, politics, communication, decision-making, conflict and group processes. Not recommended for students in Commerce programs.
cmCourseInfo.title: Organizational Behaviour
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Enrolment in the Employment Relations program (ASSPE1535/ASMAJ1535) or 4.0 or more FCEs and a minimum cgpa of 2.3

courses.name: Finance and Accounting for HR/IR Professionals

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces Employment Relations students to accounting and finance procedures and concepts used by Human Resources managers and Industrial Relations experts in organizations such as government, trade unions and companies. The course covers both managerial and financial accounting with an applied focus to the employment relations function within organizations. It is geared specifically to students who aspire to become HR/Labour Relations professionals where essential knowledge in finance and accounting is required. Note: Course will not count towards Rotman Commerce program requirements.
cmCourseInfo.title: Finance and Accounting for HR/IR Professionals

courses.name: Canadian Employment Law & the Non-Union Workplace

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on the law governing employment in a non-unionized workplace. Specifically, it will cover every phase of the employment relationship from hiring to termination and beyond and the rights and obligations of employers and employees as developed by the Courts and under employment-related statutes (namely the <u>Employment Standards Act, 2000</u> and the <u>Human Rights Code</u>.) The course will also cover provisions from the <u>Occupational Health and Safety Act</u>.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Employment Law & the Non-Union Workplace

notes.name: Course Note

courses.name: Canadian Labour Law & the Unionized Workplace

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will focus on the laws impacting unionized workplaces. It will cover every phase of the Ontario Labour Relations Act, 1995 (the “LRA”) from union organizing, certification, negotiation and bargaining, collective agreement arbitration, retention of bargaining rights and decertification and termination of bargaining rights.
cmCourseInfo.title: Canadian Labour Law & the Unionized Workplace
